I am opposed to the proposed scheduling of Mitragyna speciosa, an herbal dietary supplement, and its constituent alkaloids, mitragynine and 7-OH-mitragynine. Based on personal experience, I do not believe that kratom conveys a high potential for misuse or abuse.

I am a 42-year old husband and father of two. I have suffered from ankylosing spondylitis since 2010 and am under the care of a rheumatologist. Over the course of my disease, I have constantly battled the toxic effects of my medications (anti-TNF, DMARD, NSAIDS, OTC analgesics and RX analgesics) on my liver.

I have been taking kratom in the form of tea brewed from plain, ground leaf since November 2015 to support my health and wellness. Since drinking kratom tea, I have been able to reduce and/or eliminate my use of analgesics (both OTC and controlled) reversing poor AST/ALT levels. My routine blood labs ordered by my rheumatologist have returned to within normal range. 

Although kratom has been identified by the DEA as a drug of abuse, my personal experience contradicts the DEA's claims. Since starting to drink kratom tea, I have experienced a marked increase in my ability to be more active in the lives of my family members. I actually have the energy to throw a football with my son. I can get on the floor and play with my daughter. I lead an active life again.

I have experienced no compulsion to take ever-increasing amounts of kratom, nor have I experienced any tolerance issues. I am drinking less kratom tea than I did when I started, and have been taking a stable amount for months on end.

I have experienced only minor withdrawal issues. I have stopped drinking kratom tea on occasion and experienced a discontinuation syndrome that was a little worse than stopping coffee. The symptoms are minor irritability and headache. The worst part was increased joint and tendon pain due to underlying chronic disease.

I urge the DEA to take a measured approach to kratom, one that errs on the side of chronically ill Americans, and maintain kratom's current regulatory classification as non-controlled. This will allow research into this promising herbal dietary supplement to continue, which would otherwise evaporate if kratom is moved to Schedule I.

Listing Kratom as Schedule 1 would guarantee that research into its effects, side-effects, potential uses and development of pharmacological analogs and derivatives would be completely blocked.  Once listed as Schedule 1, it will remain with that designation for decades if not longer.  For example, marijuana which has never caused an overdose death is STILL listed as Schedule 1 even though many states have legalized it.
   Further, the damage of scheduling a novel plant product goes far beyond blocking any further research.  It automatically criminalizes large numbers of casual users including those dealing with opioid addiction.  These people are subject to court and long term incarceration.  What a waste of human resources!  In practice, often Kratom is used to mitigate opioid withdrawal--potentially avoiding serious consequences of much stronger opioids like heroin, oxycontin, hydrocodone, etc.

My name is John.  I am 34 and work as a handyman, mechanic, and farm hand. I oppose the DEA putting kratom on the list of Schedule I controlled substances.  I feel the ban is unwarranted because Schedule I drugs like heroin, and cocaine are narcotics with serious side effects while kratom has a very mild effect and no negative effects that I have found in three years of taking it.

My experience pre-kratom: 

I suffered severe chronic pain due to muscle injuries that wouldn't heal, as well as back and head injuries due to a couple of serious vehicle accidents.  My doctor said I also had advanced arthritis and that my joints looked like those of a 70-year-old man.  I had been dealing with these problems since I was 18.  I went to many doctors and spent tens of thousands of dollars but they could not figure out what was wrong.  I was recently diagnosed with Hashimoto's, an autoimmune disorder, as the cause of the healing problems.  But now these problems are so bad they cannot be fixed.

Over this thirteen year period, doctors prescribed these drugs for me:

For pain: Opiates (Oxycodone, Methadone, Morphine).  These drugs took away my energy and made me sleepy, worthless, and lethargic.  I was too impaired to drive or work. I had to keep increasing the dose to get relief from the pain.  They were extremely addictive.  Detoxing off them was horrible.

For depression: I tried three or four common anti-depressants.  I felt like I had no emotions.  I was numb, had no energy, and felt dead inside.

For anxiety: (Diazepam and others).  They worked, but I always had an impaired feeling.  I couldn't function.

For insomnia: (Trazedone, Seraquil, Ambien). I woke up feeling horrible, angry, tense, worked up.

For side effects: I took a variety of medications to combat the side effects of the other drugs I was taking.

Transitioning from medications to kratom: 

Three years ago I detoxed off oxycodone. It took two weeks of heavy-duty detoxing.  I had to get off all pain meds to decrease my tolerance for opiates so that kratom would work.  Please note that kratom is not an opiate but it affects the same opiod receptors in the brain that they do.  Coffee and chocolate also affect these receptors and obviously are not opiates.

The kratom I take: 

I take straight kratom - the pure, dried, powdered leaf of the kratom tree, not mixed with any other substance, always the same type of leaf and always from a reputable supplier.  I take the minimum I need to based on the amount of pain I have that day. 

My experience with kratom and that of relatives and friends:

I do not experience euphoria or any negative side effects.  Kratom does not take away the pain completely, but enough that I can function.  It also provides relief from anxiety, depression, low energy, and insomnia.  Mentally it changes me back to a pre-illness state.  I no longer need to take any prescription medications.

Each individual may have a different experience - especially depending on what type of leaf they consume.  Some people say it doesn't do anything.

The following list of kratom's effects is from DEA's "Drugs of Abuse" (page 84).

I have not experienced these symptoms:
Itching, constipation, increased urination, anorexia.

I have not experienced these symptoms or heard of anyone else experiencing them:
Psychotic symptoms, including hallucinations, delusion, and confusion.

I have not experienced these symptoms, but I might if the kratom was too potent or I took too much:
Nausea and sweating.

I have experienced the opposite of these symptoms:
Loss of appetite.  Weight loss.  Insomnia. 

I have experienced these symptoms or a variation of them:
Dry mouth - Yes.
Improved physical energy - Yes, definitely.
Stimulant effects and increased alertness - Improves my mood rather than being a stimulant.
Increased talkativeness - Maybe a little, due to better mood.
Sedative effects - It is calming and reduces anxiety.
Psychological addiction - No worse than coffee.

In conclusion, kratom gave me my life back after eight years of taking prescription pain killers.  I had lost everything - my family, my house, and all my possessions.  My cousin suggested getting off prescription medications and trying kratom.  Three years later I am a new father who is able to help support his family.  I am in the process of rebuilding my life.  I do not want to go back to my old life.  That is what will happen if this ban goes into effect.

For more information please refer to the American Kratom Association website which contains links to the latest scientific studies on kratom - www.AmericanKratom.org/science.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I stand firmly in opposition to scheduling kratom or any of its active alkaloids this December. As a pre-med student, I have been closely following the growing opioid epidemic across the US. In the context of that scourge, kratom appears to be a great help to many recovering opiate users: it provides many of the benefits of methadone or suboxone maintenance therapy to patients too remote or too poor to afford going to more traditional clinics. Additionally, the risk of deadly respiratory depression from overdose seems virtually nonexistent (a rare quality in opioid analgesics), and subjective withdrawal syndromes seem less severe than those associated with traditional maintenance drugs like buprenorphine.

Moreover, scheduling mitragynine and associated alkaloids poses a significant threat to clinical research. These compounds represent a promising frontier in pharmaceutical research. In the next few decades, kratom-based drug discovery research has serious potential to yield a less harmful alternative to disastrously addictive and diversion-prone drugs like Vicodin and Oxycontin.

For these reasons, and for the relative scarcity of cases of drastic harm due to kratom use, I urge the DEA to refrain from scheduling kratom, mitragynine, and the related alkaloids.

Thank you.

documents.commentText: I am writing to oppose the proposed scheduling of kratom by the DEA. Kratom is a relatively mild substance that has been safely used by millions of people for pain relief and as an aid in overcoming opioid or other addictions. Only a very few deaths have been associated with kratom, and nearly all of them have occurred in combination with other substances. On the other hand, deaths due to opiate and opioid overdoses have exploded in recent years, and continued access to kratom may very well prove essential in helping to bring this terrible death toll down again. At this point it would definitely be reasonable to require age identification for kratom purchase, inspect shipments for contamination and warn purchasers of potentially harmful drug interactions. An outright ban on kratom is very likely to cause far more damage than it would ever prevent, and have an adverse effect on public perception of current drug policy in this country.

documents.commentText: I'm thirty-five years old and the manager of my family owned auto parts business. I'm very active physically, including biking, hiking, running, and cross country skiing. I started using Kratom as an endurance workout supplement recommended by a friend. I used it a couple times a week and it worked wonders for energy, muscle fatigue, and pain associated with exercising. I stopped using it because I heard it had some withdrawal potential. I personally didn't experience anything of the sort, but was only using it a few times a week. Then about a year later I contracted Lyme disease. Fatigue, joint and muscle aches, depression, and gastrointestinal issues were some of the issues I was facing. I decided to try Kratom again since some of the symptoms I was having could be potentially relieved with it. Again, it worked very well. Overall fatigue, muscle and joint aches, and even the depression were alleviated. I was taking it more this time, about twice a day. Once in the morning, sometimes in the afternoon, and right before bed. After a few months I decided to stop to make sure I wouldn't have the withdrawal I had heard about, since I was taking it more often. I had a runny nose, and some slight diarrhea for about two days, but nothing like what I had heard. All of the Lyme symptoms came back so I started taking it again. I was told how to take it from the friend who recommended it, so I didn't have any issues with taking too much that I've also heard about. My Lyme wasn't treated early so it's being very stubborn. I've had several courses of antibiotics, none of which have been able to rid me of the bacteria as of yet. Hopefully soon. Without Kratom, I'm not sure what I would have done to deal with Lyme. I just feel lucky to have it as an option. Also, I haven't had a cold or a flu in the two years since I have been taking it, which is odd for me, I typically get colds that turn into sinus infections two or three times a year. Not sure if it has anything to do with the Kratom, but it sure seems like it. Please keep Kratom legal. It has the potential to help so many people at a fraction of the cost of the medicine it would take to do the same thing, and it's all natural. Put an age limit on it, regulate its quality, but please don't take it away.

OTC pain products are supposed to manage this type of discomfort, but they don't work for every one, including me. I've found that regular use of OTC pain products such as ibuprofen and other NSAID's all cause me stomach pain, issues with my GI tract, and other side effects. I've been using it as needed for several years without any signs of side effects. I've always gone to my doctor for an annual physical and my results have been unaffected (my physical health is excellent) which I consider a reasonable indicator that kratom is not causing unforeseen health issues. 

Kratom doesn't eliminate the need for opiate pain medication for severe pain. I recently cracked a rib and was prescribed painkillers that I used for a few days. So I don't see kratom as a magic bullet for all situations, but for me kratom is perfect for the level of discomfort in my knee and foot (and occasionally back pain from just getting older). I use it in concert with other supplements (such as curcuminoids, omega-3 & -6, and hyaluronic acid) and it has allowed me to stay active and enjoy the benefits I get from physical activity. 

For me, here are the main keys to successful use of kratom:

2. I only purchase it from one online supplier that I've found to be reputable and the product consistent. I'm not saying there is only one reputable supplier, I'm sure there are several, but I've built up a level of trust with one in particular.

Here are a few comments about kratom, outside of how effective I've found it for my needs.

1. I personally don't think kratom should be sold in "head shops", convenience stores, or gas stations. The sale of kratom in shiny packaging isn't proper. It doesn't suppress the respiratory system, it doesn't cause people to stay awake for days, it isn't used intravenously so the spread of disease isn't a factor, it doesn't impair judgement or reaction times (or if it does it can't be any worse than alcohol and then age restrictions come into play)... kratom just isn't that powerful.

I.

Before I begin, I just want to comment on the comment guidelines here because I think they are very relevant to my discussion as to why kratom being placed on Schedule 1 is completely absurd.  You are asking commenters to be scientific and to provide adequately sourced information [cf. item #10 on "Tips for Submitting Effective Comments"] so that the DEA can make a substantive and intelligently reasoned determination as to whether or not kratom is a genuine threat to public safety and thus worthy of creating a regulation that could, theoretically, put thousands of non-violent users of kratom in a Federal prison and cost taxpayers billions of dollars.  

But has the DEA done due diligence in making sure that kratom is significantly dangerous enough to warrant such heavy handed action?  No, of course not.  They put kratom on Schedule 1 by executive fiat, without any input from the public whatsoever last August, and more importantly, without any scientific testing to buttress such an extreme and potentially costly action.

Thus we can reasonably determine that the placing of kratom on Schedule 1 is most likely politically motivated, coming as it did right before Congress was getting ready to determine budget allocations for the DEA.  Also, it is worth noting that several states had initiatives on the ballot that would make cannabis either legal for recreational use, or for medical use, and it is likely that the DEA knew these would pass and was thus afraid that their budget allocations for 2017 would be decreased significantly.

Here I could launch into a very long and sad story about what a complete and utter failure the "War on Drugs" that the DEA has inflicted on the American public has been over the last 40 years of my lifetime.  Hundreds of thousands of lives rendered impotent or severely damaged, virtual centuries of incarceration cumulatively, at a cost to the taxpayer which has offered extremely little return on the public good.  And for what?  To prevent citizens from using a plant that God has provided, and which, after years of testing, has been determined to be enormously useful for many sufferers of various ailments as an effective and inexpensive medicine, and which will most likely be legal within the entire U.S. within a generation.

So let us begin by suggesting that the motivation for making kratom a new "boogeyman" for the DEA is entirely political, and once again, they are making a grievous error as they did with cannabis.  How can any other conclusion be drawn when it was only sustained public outrage at the DEA's imperious and non-scientically rigorous scheduling of kratom as a Schedule 1 "drug" that forced them to open up this comment period?  Institutional power in the swamp known as Washington, D.C. is almost entirely determined by how much money said institution receives from the taxpayers, and if those budgets don't go up every year, that institution is in danger of eventually being eradicated altogether.  

That the DEA and the FDA are working "hand in glove" on this destructive policy making is shameful.  They are willing to sacrifice even more lives on the altar of their institutional survival, and to sustain their ridiculous and nonsensical "War on Drugs" ad inifintum, all over a plant that, like cannabis, is safe, non addictive, cost effective, and medically useful.  They have not learned from their mistakes, and so I daresay the loss of public trust they will suffer if they continue in such a foolhardy manner will actually bring about the very thing they fear the most: institutional fecklessness.

II.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a safe and effective herbal supplement that is not known to be addictive or to have dangerous or toxic side effects, but is known to be very useful in a number of scenarios.

Kratom is a medicinal plant from South East Asia that has enjoyed safe use for some thousands of years.  Kratom has many uses, including helping treat panic attacks without strong medications, having an anti-depressant effect without the problems associated with common antidepressants, and helping with the nausea, vomiting and other symptoms encountered during opiate or other narcotic withdrawal.

Opiate and narcotic addicts can and do use Kratom to assist with many symptoms when detoxifying from an addiction. These drugs are notoriously difficult to stop taking and anything that can help an addict kick their habit could be nothing but good.  Given the damage that opiate addictions cause to both individuals and the general public, the scheduling of Kratom would seem to actually be against the public interest.

Kratom has other benefits as well.  Some people find it very useful in controlling panic disorders.  Some find it effective enough that they are no longer required to take the dangerous benzodiazapenes, which the CDC has determined to be a substance of abuse, especially when combined with opiates or narcotics (please see preceding paragraph).  Reducing the use of these powerful drugs in the general population will lead to reduced exposure and reliance on these drugs.  Scheduling Kratom would be against this public interest.

Many people find that Kratom increases their pain tolerance, many times to the point where other, more powerful medications become less needed, or even unnecessary.  Reducing reliance on powerful pain relievers, including narcotics and opiates, would seem to be strongly in the public interest.  Scheduling Kratom would prevent this reduction and therefore not be in the public interest.

Personally knowing sufferers of both severe chronic pain and a panic disorders, the new CDC guidelines on benzodiazapenes has forced them to make a choice between proper treatment for their pain and proper treatment for their panic disorders.  As a result, they must go untreated for one or the other, making their futures uncertain.  Knowing that a herbal supplement is available to them, should they wish to take advantage of it, which might well help them contain their panic disorders and possibly help them reduce their levels of pain, I would be very disappointed that they would not have Kratom available should they wish to use it.  In fact, I think they should be taking advantage of it now.  For this reason I would like Kratom to remain available to my friends should they desire to make use of it.  Scheduling Kratom is not in my friends' interest.

We as a nation have learned from the War On Drugs that prohibition doesn't work to control consumption and has many severe unintended consequences.  Kratom is not a dangerous drug of abuse that requires scheduling, in fact it has a number of uses that make it a valuable supplement to have available on the open market.

Due to all these reasons, I believe that scheduling Kratom is not only unnecessary, but would be actively against the public interest.

     My daughter was diagnosed with chronic leukemia (CML) 5 years ago. She has to take chemotherapy every single day for the rest of her life. Without it, she would die in a very short time. The side effects of the chemotherapy make life unbearable. It is a struggle from morning until night, every single day for the rest of her life. No day is a good day. I often feel as though she only chooses the chemotherapy over death because of us, her family.

     I can relate to her because I was diagnosed with stage 4 esophageal cancer recently. No cure for that either. We walk the same road and live in hope that doors will open to us. Millions of dollars are spent in research for a cure. Hopefully someday that will happen, but in the meantime many people suffer and die. We pray to God that he hears us and helps in our dilemma. 

     Unlike the fact that there is little help for cancer, there is help for other life altering medical issues. Kratom is known to help so many people, in so many ways. My grandaughter was struck by a motor vehicle while walking on the sidewalk 15 years ago. She spent the better part of the following 7 years in the hospital fighting a chronic staph infection and fighting to keep her limbs from being amputated. Unfortunately, although she was able to keep her limbs, she lives in agony. No day is a good day for her. She has some amazing doctors that have done their best to make her comfortable over the years since her accident. Unfortunately all the pain medications have done little to help her pain and have unbearable side effects. I've often been afraid that I would lose my granddaughter. I've often been afraid that the pain and resulting isolation and depression would become too much for her to bear. Then she discovered Kratom. What a lifesaver! I have my granddaughter back! She is smiling again. She is an active participant in her own life for the first time since her accident in 2001. I cannot imagine that she could ever go back to just barely surviving every day. 

     Used responsibly, Kratom can be beneficial to those that suffer from chronic pain and it does not have all the horrible side effects that most prescription pain medications have. It is a natural supplement that has the ability to aid people with many issues. It can be taken safely and is immediately available to those who benefit from it. It is beyond my comprehension why anyone would ever consider making something so beneficial, illegal. The true crime would be to taking this leaf away from the people that benefit from it so much. My name is Richard Freed, and I am a 70-year-old retired full professor at a Land Grant university as well as a retired management consultant.

I am strongly opposed to the DEA scheduling kratom in any way. This plant (and the alkaloids it contains) should be left unscheduled. It should be available as a botanical, and the United States government should help ensure that it and other botanicals are regulated for quality and potency.

I had never heard of kratom until the DEA first threatened to schedule it earlier this year. Because my daughter is disabled with a severely painful and incurable disease and cannot take opioids because of their deleterious side effects, I immediately began to research this plant. After reading many scientific studies and hundreds of positive (mostly glowing) anecdotal accounts, I bought some kratom for her. No pharmaceutical medication has helped her in the 20 years she has suffered from her debilitating disease. I am stunned to report that five milligrams of kratom relieves her pain and bladder pressure for five hours and treats her co-morbid anxiety disorder more effectively than any benzodiazepine she has ever been prescribed.

Last September, I had a four-hour surgery that involved multiple spinal fusions, and I was in the hospital for eight nights. I came home with fentanyl patches, which left me light-headed and dazed and which I stopped using after about a week, and tablets of oxycodone. I am thankful that the doctor provided the post-surgical pain relief that I needed. Concerned, however, about using the opioids with another CNS depressant I am prescribed, I decided to take 4 milligrams of kratom in the evening so that I wouldnt stop breathing at night.

Four mg. of kratom controlled my pain much better than 10 mg. of oxycodone.

By attempting to schedule kratom, the DEA is acting as if nothing has been learned by the decades-long War on Drugs that has ruined the lives of millions. Making the plant illegal will not stop people from using it any more than the illegality of any number of substances has prevented people from using those drugs. We cant even prevent prisoners, people watched day and night, from using illegal drugs.

But kratom is not a drug; it is a plant that has been used for centuries to help people be more productive and to control their pain. We are a free country, and our government should not control what adults put into their own bodies, unless that action has severe social consequences, equally or more severe than alcohol. 

Yes, we must try as best we can to regulate kratoms quality and purity. Yes, we must study its effects and consequences so that if it is harmful in some ways, we can treat those harms medically rather than criminally. Most importantly, we must study this plant because it could lead to breakthroughs in pain management that are far less addictive and lethal than opioids. 

Designating kratom Schedule 1 will make such breakthroughs almost impossible. Scheduling kratom at all will prevent tens of thousands of law-abiding American citizens from treating their pain, controlling their anxiety, enhancing their sense of well being, and weaning themselves from the scourge of opioid addiction. Scheduling this herb or its alkaloids will not stop people from using it; it will make criminals of huge numbers of those citizens who will continue to use the plant, illegally, because they find it safer and more efficacious than anything that can be prescribed.

To the DEA, re: the proposed scheduling of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine (i.e. a ban on Kratom):

I implore you not to impose drug scheduling upon this natural medicinal. Kratom is fairly benign and no deaths have been directly linked to its use. It represents no national health crisis or emergency and warrants no federal restrictions. It should in no way imaginable be grouped with drugs such as heroin, drugs that have no clinical use, whatsoever. Kratom, however, is a tremendous benefit to persons such as I, who suffer from general anxiety disorder. Aside from meditation et al., shown only to be 20% effective at best, the course of therapy for sufferers of GAD and etc. is typically Xanax plus an adjunct (often an SSRI). I my case, I have Serotonin Syndrome and cannot take SSRIs. Every other adjunct has had little to no effect on my condition with the exception of Kratom.

Kratom has a very low profile for abuse and has no adverse health consequences. The few cases of illness associated with Kratom have had nothing to do with the medicinal per se, but with the much harsher (and truly illegal) drugs having been consumed in conjunction with Kratom. The suggestion that Kratom has no health benefits is very misinformed. I am a case in point. I use Kratom, carefully and in studied doses, and it has been of great benefit in remediation of my GAD. I have no desire to be labelled a criminal of the first degree by using this medicinal. Further, regulation will merely result in Big Pharma(tm) profiteering whereas normal market forces decree its cost at this time. What benefit can result in putting Kratom in the same category as herion, cocaine, etc.? It will make criminals out of ordinary citizens, or deprive them of a medicinal that is mild and efficacious. If allowed to migrate to a prescription-only paradigm, the cost will escalate as Big Pharma provides a distilled variant, not to mention the cost of doctors' appointments. Will scheduling of M/7-H prevent abuse and death across the country? Kratom is not particularly ripe for abuse and no deaths have ever been attributed to its sole use.

In short, scheduling of M/7-H (aka Kratom) is entirely misguided, unnecessary, and abhorrently unsympathetic. Thank you for your time. Now, please devote your time and attention to true health crises such as drugs crossing our borders, the national crack and heroin epidemic, and the hyperbolic rise in prescriptions and health care. Beverly Hills, MI.

documents.commentText: I have been very impressed by this substance, even in the crude forms available through mom/pop style vendors across the internet.  A crucial bit of information not discussed often enough is that this substance comes in so many varieties, some with stronger opioid (mood lifting and mild euphoric) effects while others have almost none and provide more stimulant like effects, and also many others with effects in between these.  Most types, In their mildest forms, have a pleasant activating effect like strong coffee, but actually more predictable, and WITHOUT the painful headaches and other ill effects from caffeine withdrawal.  The milder forms with more opioid-like effects also have the enormous benefit of minimal withdrawal symptoms, nothing at all like what I understand persons dependent on opioid pain medications can experience.  As with all agents, the key is what specific form is being evaluated - I am taking about forms with milder opioid like effects (lower concentration forms  with mainly partial mu agonist activity).  I believe there are some available with stronger opioid effects that may cause some uncomfortable withdrawal for some persons, but I do not believe the strongest forms with this problem are even available for sale anymore ANYWHERE in the US, which is a very good thing.  I have read tremendously hopeful anecdotes of persons using this to wean off their prescription pain medications, and can understand how this is possible - it makes excellent sense from a pharmacological perspective. Opioid withdrawal causes profound suppression of natural activating hormones in a person's body leading to well known crippling tiredness and apathy (suppression of testosterone, among others).  This substance may help boost similar chemicals and make the process much less terrible for persons needing weaning from opioid dependence.  There is tremendous potential here.  Banning this substance and ending the current exploration of its legitimate uses would be a HUGE MISTAKE (especially in the interest of public safety given all that we know and have seen regarding its safety).  I hope more efforts are made to explore its intelligent use for helping to treat our current opioid epidemic and not to BAN this potentially helpful substance in what appears a misguided attempt to address this self same crisis.  This substance is nothing like other schedule 1 opioids - its similarities to opioids are superficial but perhaps just enough to allow it to be potentially useful. I teach high school in a Title I district that serves primarily low-income students. I also suffer from an autoimmune disease that can flair up painfully, without warning, and sometimes for weeks or months on end. When it does, it impacts every area of my life, including my ability to sleep and my ability function at work. My students need me in top form - not exhausted, in pain, or spaced out on prescription pain meds - and kratom is the only thing that allows this to happen.

I've been using kratom for a little over a year now, and its effects have dramatically impacted my life for the better. Different strains have different effects - some are energizing, some are relaxing, and nearly all of them help ease physical pain. 

During the day, I tend to use the energizing strains, which provide me with an energy boost similar to coffee, but minus the jitters, and with the added benefit of greatly reducing the amount of pain I'm in. (And since my condition is actually exacerbated by the acidity of brewed coffee, being able to skip the coffee but still get the energy is a double benefit.) At no point do these strains mentally impair me or have any effect that could be remotely described as a "high", an intoxication, or an altered state of consciousness. I absolutely cannot say the same for prescription pain medications - which I refuse to take during the day, because they DO mentally impair me and interfere with my work. 

In the evenings, I use the more relaxing kratom strains, which tend to offer the strongest pain relief. Some of these have an anti-anxiety, stress relieving effect as well, but like their energizing counterparts, they are not any sort of "high." They simply make it easier to unwind and decompress after a stressful day, and they help ease physical pain so I can focus on whatever work I might have brought home with me, then get a good night's sleep. And unlike prescription pain meds, they don't leave me feeling groggy and sluggish in the morning.

Kratom is absolutely NOT a drug, and in my experience with many different strains, I've found several things to be true, time and again: it is not addictive (no compulsion for "more more more" etc), it has no recreational value as a "high", and the absolute worst thing that happens if I accidentally ingest too much is I get a tummy ache.  That's it. If we're labeling things Schedule I for giving people a stomach ache, I look forward to seeing the Wal-Mart post-Halloween sale aisle up next for Schedule I. Please feel free to put Taco Bell on the list too. 

Banning kratom would make criminals out of regular people who are simply trying to live our lives well-rested and without constant pain. For me, the loss of kratom would mean having to choose between constant pain, and relying on prescription pain medications whose side-effects would inhibit my life almost as much as the pain itself. This is not an acceptable choice. Not when both of the above can be avoided with a perfectly safe, completely natural tea leaf that has no more business being labeled a Schedule I "drug" than something you might buy from the Drive-Thru at Starbucks.

documents.commentText:
I am attorney and a law-abiding citizen. A few years ago, my wife, who is only 31, had a traumatic injury to her spinal cord which led her to develop severe neuropathic pain and a disorder called Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) -- which has been labeled as an "orphan disease" because almost nobody is studying it or attempting to find treatments that work for it despite its prevalence. CRPS has been described variously as "the pain of cancer without the relief of death" and "the feeling of rubbing salt into a raw wound using sandpaper, 24 hours a day," among other things. It is colloquially referred to as the "suicide disease" because so many people with advanced CRPS choose to end their lives. On a scientifically-normed pain scale, it ranks higher than the pain from serial amputation of the fingers.

Opiate medications, while helpful for CRPS patients who are getting over flares, can actually make the pain worse in the long-term. There are no cures for CRPS, only hopes of stopping the disease from spreading and mitigating the pain. The most effective drug proven to do this is ketamine, however, inpatient ketamine treatments run $60,000 on average and are not generally covered by insurance companies because ketamine therapy is considered "investigational" (meanwhile, it is the ONLY thing that has worked for my wife).

Kratom, too, proves effective for managing CRPS-related flares, without the negative side effects of opiates for CRPS patients (i.e., it does not advance the disease). While I understand the DEA's concern with opiate and other drug abuse, (1) Kratom is not an opiate; and (2) the final effect of the DEA's rulings should not be to wage war on people in chronic pain. My wife and others with CRPS are suffering. Please do not take away one of the few coping mechanisms at their disposal to make their day-to-day struggles, which are more intense than people without CRPS can ever imagine, bearable.

documents.commentText:
Please be mindful and judicious when considering Banning kratom. It will expand the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. 
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has never killed anyone and it has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

In the long run, what we really need is a new, post-prohibition drug classification system that's based on science and best public health practices. Kratom is suffering the same fate as countless other medicinal plants that have been used by our ancestors for millennia -- there's no profit incentive for pharmaceutical companies to do years of clinical research to gain FDA approval for a plant that they can't patent for prescription use, which leaves it in a regulatory gray area. Please think of the people and not the pharmaceutical companies and their profits.

.

Kratom has helped me and many others. I urge you to carefully review and consider the personal comments you receive. I strongly oppose the scheduling of kratom. This seems a huge injustice and step backwards from the free, progressive country I thought I was a part in.

I would like to provide a personal and fair account of what role Mitragyna Speciosa, or "Kratom" has had in my life. 

I am a 20 year old college student attending a public university in Oregon, and am currently in my third year. During my childhood I was diagnosed with OCD and ADHD, and anxiety and depression shortly after. In recent years, my depression, anxiety, and subsequent social anxiety have been the most debilitating and lowered my quality of life, at times very severely. Medications prescribed to me have varied over the years; most recently being Zoloft for depression and anxiety, Xanax for anxiety,  and a stimulant ADHD medication. 

In my experience, Zoloft slightly betters my overall depression condition, but does not do anything for my anxiety. Periods of "situational depression" have hit me frequently, characterized by feelings of hopelessness and severe depression usually due to a circumstance or life event affecting me at the time. Zoloft, nor any other of the many medications I have tried would help during these times. Feeling there was no solution, I would sometimes turn to alcohol or other unhealthy activities in a desperate attempt to make me feel better, but doing so would always make my situation worse. This is where Kratom is so different.

My first experience with Kratom was midway through my freshman year of college. I had read many reports of its helpfulness with conditions similar to my own while doing research into depression and anxiety remedies. When a personal situation left me more depressed than I had been in years, I decided to order some and give it a try. Suddenly, somehow, I simply felt OK. I had a positive outlook, my mood was no longer negative, I was able to put my anxieties and constant worry in perspective. The most remarkable part: I didn't feel like I had taken anything. There was no "high", no "buzz", or any altered state that was simply making me forget about my problems. I was my fully functional self, but I was now feeling alright when I felt like I couldn't. The effects only lasted a few hours but the new outlook I had on my situation persisted long after.

After realizing the great potential of Kratom, I began using it somewhat frequently, garnering a wide range of experiences that will help me describe the plant, and all it has done for me, in this comment.

Kratom's effects can be felt, but not in a way that resembles any form of intoxication I know of. The positive changes are very subtle, but more noticeable than other remedies such as kava, magnesium, and Chamomille tea. This is important, as being able to notice when I start feeling better makes Kratom more useful than something that may be placebo, or have effects that are so mild that they are of no help. Unlike something like marijuana, which has potential to make some happier but no consistency in its benefits, I have found that I can always rely on Kratom to increase my mood. This has made it a life changer for me in regards to my  depression. In times that I feel hopeless Kratom gives me a more positive perspective, feelings of reassurance and that "everything will be ok", and an energy and drive to keep going at times when it is the most difficult. 

One of Kratom's other major benefits in my life is the relief it provides in social situations. I lack confidence at times, and this frequently gives way to anxiety and hesitation when interacting with others. Kratom does not help my social anxiety by disinhibiting me as something like alcohol or Xanax would; it seems to directly increase my confidence and social energy. I have a desire to talk to others that I would ordinarily shy away from after taking Kratom. It doesn't just make social situations I encounter easier, it makes me want to actively approach them. I feel that I am having conversations on my own, not that a drug is allowing me to participate.

I understand the need for research into the properties of Kratom, and am in support of learning more about the plant. Rushing to prohibit it now, however, is a very dangerous move. It would be of great detriment to ban and bury something that could potentially be of great help to so many people. If Kratom were banned, it would easily become forgotten and overlooked. The public is in no danger in the meantime before a decision is made on how Kratom should be available in the US. I have taken too much before and thrown up, but luckily Kratom has a "ceiling" of effects so it is simply impossible for one to be hurt from taking too much. There are so many people who have legitimate use for kratom, and companies selling it for false purposes need to be eliminated, as they have obviously been successful in painting an untrue picture of what Kratom actually is. I hope my and others' reports are showing the true nature of Kratom to those who previously may have rejected it.

Sincerely,

John Drake

Since I had no medical insurance at the time, I had to cope with the pain without any remedy or relief.  I futilely tried all over the counter remedies with little or no success.  At this time, I was dating a woman who was being prescribed numerous medications (neurontin, gabapentin, flexoril, ibuprophen) including the narcotic Vicodine. I was taking 8 to 9 Vicodine a day with no relief from my annoying and chronic pain.  

Being desperate for any relief from my chronic pain, I resorted to using Cocaine as a remedy for some relief.  Prior to sustaining the injury to my neck, I am ashamed to admit that I was regularly using Cocaine on a recreational basis.  Since I knew that the Cocaine tended to numb me all over, I began to use Cocaine excessively to numb me and my chronic pain. Dear Members of the DEA,
There have been many "herbal" remedies touted for many years. The marketer's of these products made some very strong (as well as false) claims as to the efficacious nature of their blends. There was even a time when machines were sold to extract paparavine from lettuce as a natural pain reliever. This "substance" was called "Lopium." So, after many years of attempting these grand failures, I perceived Kratom as an over-marketed failure, just like all the rest.
I was very intrigued, when a long-time medically dependent opioid patient was able to stop using all opioid narcotics (including Methadone) and he claimed to be as pain free as on the opioids. I immediately searched for Kratom, in August of this year, and while I could order the leaves, there was a warning about your rescheduling of Kratom coming approximately 45 days later. I have spent most of my medical career involved in the study of "ethnobotanicals" and I will not flush my career over pain relief that I now receive from opioid related pharmaceuticals.
My desire was to order a kilo of Kratom, study the leaves for comparative safety, and use myself as a test case as I have a rare form of Cystic Fibrosis that attacks the GI system and the pancreas. Cystic Fibrosis patients produce few to no endorphins of their own and, to me, there is no difference between a bruise and a broken leg. Before my disease situation was diagnosed, pain ruled my life. Pain told me when I could wake, fall asleep, eat, and even pleasure my wife. So, as dearly as I hated to do it, I made a pain contract and my life turned around a full 180 degrees. With the CDC's edict on opioid abuse, not contractual use by a doctor one sees regularly and stores all opioid medications in a locked and secure location, pain patients are being dumped to a severely disabled state all across the country. This is neither the prevention of abuse, nor is it anything resembling compassion.
I urge you as well as your counterparts to seriously research this substance. I would happily join the research program as it was my studies with American Indian ritual hallucinogen use and my studies with LSA that paved the way for Eli Lilly to pose that research on Prozac was safe in the daily clinical setting, although I have never met any American Indian who would use such substances daily. If Kratom can safely wean a person from Methadone and even act as a first line detox/maintenance substance, it must be studied very seriously. I wish I could tell you how successful it was for me, but I do not take any old pile of leaves marketed by a foreign country. It takes a great deal of "anecdotal" evidence to convince me of the benefit of any herbal remedy, but this particular substance (Kratom) has piqued my, deeply concerned, interest.

To whom it may concern:

I am writing you to provide my personal experience with Kratom herbal supplements in the hopes that it will help to keep it within reach of everyone that it helps. I am 44 years old and have been suffering from Fibromyalgia, Neuropathy, Mood Swings and Blood Pressure issues for several years. I have also had several back surgeries and disk replacements in my neck.

A friend of mine suggested I try Kratom to help me with some of my health issues I have been dealing with. I have been consuming Kratom for a little over a year now and I cannot fully describe how it has helped me in my day to day life. Kratom helps me with pain management, it helps me to focus and also gives me energy to get up and function around the house.

Shelby Campbell

documents.commentText:
The war on drugs has been a failure - a lesson we should have learned from our experience almost 100 years ago with alcohol. 

The answer is legalization, regulation, and harm mitigation - and the public is rapidly coming to this point of view. 

Kratom is a chance to do it right:
  - We should not criminalize the large numbers of people who already use it.
  - Research into the the benefits (and harms) of krater is urgently needed, especially among those individuals who claim relief from serious pain or other afflictions. 
  - Prohibiting kratom will add all those users to all the other illegal drug users. It can't be good for respect for the law if most of the population is ignoring the laws. 

We have seen the ill affects of enforcement recently with efforts to make prescription opioids harder to get. The users turn to heroin, which unscrupulous dealer mix with fentanyl - and the death rate soars. Surely you have seen the news articles of parents found comatose in the car, with kids buckled in car seats in the back. Or the 7-year old who went to school and told the bus driver - on the way home - that her parents were dead. You can blame our irrational drug policy for all of these - I do.

documents.commentText:
I was extremely upset when I learned that the DEA was planning to make Kratom a schedule 1 substance.  As someone who works in the pharmacy industry, this action defies all manner of logic and reason to me.

I discovered Kratom a year ago when trying to assist my fianc with weaning off of Oxycodone.  He was prescribed this pain killer for ruptured discs in his back.     As you must know, the pain relief provided by Oxy also comes with the added bonus of rapid addiction and a need to increase the dose as the patient develops a tolerance for the drug.    Tired of this dependence and its side effects, he tried to quit cold turkey to horrible effect.  The withdrawal symptoms were text book and terrifying, from the rapid heartbeat to the uncontrollable shaking.  We seriously considered taking him to the emergency room.

Enter Kratom.   Within an hour of ingesting a few grams in capsule form, he was okay.   The tachycardia had ceased.   He was calm and comfortable and no longer trying to crawl out of his skin.  In 2 days, he was done.   No more Oxy withdrawal.  No more Oxy craving.  2 DAYS!   It was like a miracle.

I researched Kratom extensively before purchasing it.  As I said before, I work in the pharmacy industry and I am not prone to ingesting drugs or herbs without ample research first.    I found no evidence that this substance would be harmful.   If fact, it was quite the contrary.   In the few cases I could find where there were claims of hospitalization due to Kratom, it was always in combination with some other substance.   Unlike prescription pain killers, Kratom does not cause respiratory depression and it is nearly impossible to overdose as ingesting too much will inevitably cause the patient to vomit.   

But is that a point I really need to make?   We live in a country where alcohol consumption kills 88,000 people a year according to The National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.   Yet, there is no ban on alcohol.  For some reason, the buzz and impairment that comes from ingesting too many margaritas is of no concern.    To claim it is in the publics interest to ban a useful herb with no harmful effects or documented fatalities, yet allow alcohol to remain legal is a smack in the face of any person with the power to reason.

documents.commentText:
This is from a plant in the coffee family, and has ample anecdotal evidence that it does, in fact, have medicinal value.  
We, as a country, made a similar error before, in placing another substance in the schedule 1 category, where it does not belong.  After decades of misery and ruined lives caused by this misclassification, we are finally starting to work our way to correct that error.  
Further, placing this in the schedule 1 category guarantees that no research will be performed to validate (or repudiate) the mass of anecdotal evidence of its medicinal qualities.  It's a horrific catch 22 that should be anathema to a rational people.  
Leave it out of schedule 1 completely, it simply does not belong there.
